author: m.kalinin
content: Under honest minority assumption, e.g. 1/3 is honest, we may say that retrievability is solved. My question would be if we can do better, i.e. how feasible it is for the base protocol to provide the same guarantee under weaker assumptions.

author: m.kalinin
content:
1. I would discern "validator has seen the data D" and "validator owns the data D", in my mental model these are proof of publication and proof of retention (storage) respectively. IMO, current version of custody game is well designed for proof of publication (the former part) but isn't suitable for the latter. Honest minority or majority assumption is one of the solutions for data retention and retrievability
2. If a large staker must provide proof of storage and/or proof of retrievability it will have to replicate data on its own infrastructure to avoid data loss and follow up penalties, a number of replication in this case will likely be lower than a number of validators but as long as data is retrievable it should be fine, IMHO

author: djrtwo
content: replication factor is not in fact the goal. ensuring data availability attacks cannot occur is the goal. PoC is supposed to help add a cryptoeconomic componnt to prevent DA attacks from being feasible. DA sampling still provides 99% fault tolerant DA guarantees
